metadata.titleEn: Snapshot of the Pliocene environment of West Kunlun region, Northwest China
metadata.description: The West Kunlun region forms the northern margin of the Tibetan Plateau, and sedimentation in this region contributed to plateau formation and its northwards expansion, as well as the development of central Asian aridification. However, the stratigraphic dating framework in this region has been ambiguous, hampering the understanding of both tectonic and environmental evolution. Here, palynological analysis was performed on the Xialafudie Formation in the West Kunlun region. Together with the palynological assemblage and megafossils found in the study section, as well as regional stratigraphic comparison, we conclude that the Xialafudie Formation was deposited during the Pliocene, and not Early Cretaceous as previously reported. The palynological assemblage of the section is mainly composed of drought-tolerant herbs and shrubs, and the percentage of conifers and broadleaved trees is very low, indicating that a dry and cold environment prevailed in the West Kunlun region during the Pliocene. Comprehensively analysed palynological data from the Tarim Basin and its surroundings show that aridification intensified in this part of central Asia during the Pliocene, as a result of long-term global cooling and regional tectonism.

background: The West Kunlun region forms the northern margin of the Tibetan Plateau, and sedimentation in this region contributed to plateau formation and its northwards expansion, as well as the development of central Asian aridification. However, the stratigraphic dating framework in this region has been ambiguous, hampering the understanding of both tectonic and environmental evolution. Located in the continent interior, and bounded to the south by the Tibetan Plateau and to the north by the central Asian mountains, northwest China has become one of the hyper-arid regions in the world, and contains one of the world’s largest deserts. It provides a major dust source for the global aerosol system, affects biogeochemical cycles and water resources and plays an important role in dust-climate feedbacks. However, the timing of the formation and subsequent evolution of this arid environment are still debated. Estimates for when aridification began range from the Eocene to the Pliocene. The rain shadow of the Tibetan Plateau, Pamir, Kunlun and Tian Shan mountains, long-term global cooling, and retreat of the Paratethys are all envisaged to have enhanced the aridification of the Asian interior and the formation of the Taklamakan Desert. Few researchers have paid attention to the environmental changes in the West Kunlun region because of the chaotic stratigraphic age constraints, hampering the understanding of the evolution of aridification in the Asian interior. Researchers can use palynomorphs to determine the relative stratigraphic age, especially when other dating methods such as radiometric isotopes in volcanic ash, palaeomagnetism and mammalian stratigraphy can be or cannot be applied. Palynological analysis is also a good proxy to reconstruct the palaeoenvironment.
research objective: Our goal was to use palynological analysis to determine the age of the Xialafudie Formation, which forms a major geological unit in the West Kunlun region, and document the evolution of the regional vegetation. The resulting palynostratigraphy can shed new light on the aridification and environmental history of this part of central Asia.
challenges: However, the stratigraphic dating framework in this region has been ambiguous, hampering the understanding of both tectonic and environmental evolution. Few researchers have paid attention to the environmental changes in the West Kunlun region because of the chaotic stratigraphic age constraints, hampering the understanding of the evolution of aridification in the Asian interior.
methods: In field work, we have found several new fossil sites nearby the published fish fossil site. Then, we have selected one of the fossil sites to collect pollen samples because this section is not very steep and easier to obtain continuous samples. Field work was conducted in the Waqia area, Tashkurgan County, in 2018. At the same time, 60 palynological samples were collected at 0.5 m intervals. Four modern top-soil pollen samples were also collected near the section for comparison. All pollen samples were prepared using the standard pollen preparation method, including 10% HCl, 10% NaOH and 40% HF. Then, a 10-μm mesh was used to remove the fine fraction and concentrate pollen by ultrasonic sieving. Identifications were based on atlases of pollen and spores, as well as modern reference slides from the collection of the Xishuangbanna Tropical Botanical Garden (XTBG), Chinese Academy of Sciences (CAS). All samples were counted to a terrestrial pollen sum of 300 pollen grains. Pollen and spore percentages were calculated based on the sum of terrestrial pollen. Palynological diagrams were illustrated using the software packages TILIA and TILIAGRAPH and pollen assemblage zones were constructed using CONISS.
findings: Here, palynological analysis was performed on the Xialafudie Formation in the West Kunlun region. Together with the palynological assemblage and megafossils found in the study section, as well as regional stratigraphic comparison, we conclude that the Xialafudie Formation was deposited during the Pliocene, and not Early Cretaceous as previously reported. Comprehensively analysed palynological data from the Tarim Basin and its surroundings show that aridification intensified in this part of central Asia during the Pliocene, as a result of long-term global cooling and regional tectonism.

Definition.Question: What is palynological analysis in the context of reconstructing paleoenvironments?
Definition.Answer: Palynological analysis involves examining pollen and spores to determine the relative stratigraphic age of geological formations and reconstruct past environments. In this context, it helps document vegetation evolution and environmental changes over geological time.

Definition.Question: What challenges are commonly faced in stratigraphic dating when reconstructing paleoenvironments?
Definition.Answer: One major challenge in stratigraphic dating is the ambiguity in the dating framework, which hampers the understanding of tectonic and environmental evolution. Chaotic stratigraphic age constraints can limit the ability to accurately reconstruct environmental changes.

Comparison.Question: What are the differences in challenges faced by researchers when determining the stratigraphic age in the West Kunlun region compared to other regions with clearer stratigraphic frameworks?
Comparison.Answer: Researchers in the West Kunlun region face challenges due to ambiguous stratigraphic age constraints, which complicate the understanding of tectonic and environmental evolution. This is in contrast to regions with clearer stratigraphic frameworks where dating may be more straightforward. The chaotic stratigraphic age constraints in the West Kunlun region make it difficult to correlate layers and require reliance on palynological analysis as a proxy, whereas other regions might utilize more direct dating methods like radiometric dating or palaeomagnetism without such constraints.

Comparison.Question: In what ways does the palynological data from the West Kunlun region provide insights into aridification compared to data from regions with different climatic histories?
Comparison.Answer: Palynological data from the West Kunlun region, characterized by a predominance of drought-tolerant herbs and shrubs, provides insights into the intensification of aridification during the Pliocene. This data contrasts with regions that have different climatic histories, where pollen assemblages might indicate a more gradual shift in vegetation types or different environmental pressures. The West Kunlun data specifically highlights the influence of long-term global cooling and regional tectonism on aridification, which might not be as pronounced in regions with milder climatic changes.

Interpretation.Question: How can palynological analysis be leveraged to overcome challenges in stratigraphic dating and enhance our understanding of environmental evolution in arid regions?
Interpretation.Answer: Palynological analysis can be used to determine the relative stratigraphic age by analyzing pollen samples. This method is particularly useful when other dating methods, like radiometric isotopes or palaeomagnetism, cannot be applied. It can also help reconstruct the palaeoenvironment and provide insights into the historical vegetation and aridification processes in a region.

Interpretation.Question: What data collection techniques could be employed to ensure continuous and reliable sampling of pollen in challenging terrains?
Interpretation.Answer: In this field, selecting fossil sites that are less steep can facilitate the collection of continuous samples. Collecting samples at regular intervals, such as 0.5 m, and using standard pollen preparation methods ensures the reliability of the data. Techniques like ultrasonic sieving and using a mesh to concentrate pollen help in preparing the samples effectively.

Interpretation.Question: What are the implications of palynological findings on the understanding of tectonic and environmental changes in regions with chaotic stratigraphic age constraints?
Interpretation.Answer: Palynological findings can clarify the age of geological formations which, in turn, illuminate the tectonic and environmental history of a region. By determining that the Xialafudie Formation was deposited during the Pliocene rather than the Early Cretaceous, researchers can better understand how global cooling and regional tectonism contributed to aridification during that period.

Few researchers have focused on environmental changes due to these constraints.

It also provides insights into vegetation evolution and environmental history.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes the aridification in the Asian interior to be a point of debate among researchers?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The timing and causes of aridification in the Asian interior are debated due to varying estimates for when it began, ranging from the Eocene to the Pliocene. Factors like the rain shadow of surrounding mountain ranges, long-term global cooling, and the retreat of the Paratethys are thought to have contributed to this aridification.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential consequences of using palynological analysis as a primary method for determining the stratigraphic age in the West Kunlun region?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Using palynological analysis as a primary method for determining the stratigraphic age in the West Kunlun region can provide a clearer understanding of the timing of sediment deposition and the evolution of regional vegetation. This approach may lead to new insights into the aridification and environmental history of central Asia by resolving ambiguities in the stratigraphic dating framework.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the objective of using palynological analysis in the context of reconstructing the palaeoenvironment of the West Kunlun region?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The objective of using palynological analysis is to determine the age of the Xialafudie Formation, document the evolution of the regional vegetation, and shed new light on the aridification and environmental history of this part of central Asia.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to establish a clear stratigraphic dating framework in the West Kunlun region for paleoenvironmental studies?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Establishing a clear stratigraphic dating framework is important because the ambiguous stratigraphic dating has hampered the understanding of both tectonic and environmental evolution in the region, and it is crucial for understanding the evolution of aridification in the Asian interior.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedural challenges are encountered when determining the stratigraphic age using palynological analysis, and how are these addressed?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: One major challenge is the ambiguous stratigraphic dating framework in the region, which complicates the understanding of environmental evolution. To address this, palynological analysis is used as a proxy to determine relative stratigraphic age, especially when other dating methods like radiometric isotopes, palaeomagnetism, and mammalian stratigraphy cannot be applied. Comprehensive regional stratigraphic comparisons and the use of palynological assemblage are employed to improve age determination.

Enablement.Answer: The collection and preparation of palynological samples involve standard pollen preparation methods, including treatments with 10% HCl, 10% NaOH, and 40% HF. A 10-μm mesh is utilized to remove fine fractions and concentrate pollen through ultrasonic sieving, with identifications based on atlases of pollen and spores, as well as modern reference slides.

Enablement.Question: How do modern palynological methods enable researchers to overcome challenges in determining stratigraphic ages in regions with ambiguous dating frameworks?
Enablement.Answer: Modern palynological methods allow researchers to determine relative stratigraphic ages by using palynomorphs, especially when other dating methods like radiometric isotopes, palaeomagnetism, and mammalian stratigraphy are not applicable. These methods help address chaotic stratigraphic age constraints and improve the understanding of environmental evolution.

Enablement.Answer: The enabling conditions involve selecting fossil sites that are not very steep, making it easier to obtain continuous samples. In the fieldwork conducted in the Waqia area, Tashkurgan County, samples were collected at 0.5 m intervals, ensuring a comprehensive and manageable data collection process.

Expectation.Question: Why might researchers expect challenges in establishing a clear stratigraphic dating framework when using palynological analysis in the West Kunlun region?
Expectation.Answer: The stratigraphic dating framework in the West Kunlun region has been ambiguous, which hampers the understanding of both tectonic and environmental evolution. This ambiguity is partly due to chaotic stratigraphic age constraints, making it difficult to accurately date and correlate sediments using palynological analysis.

Expectation.Question: What expectations might researchers have when using palynological analysis to reconstruct the palaeoenvironment, and why might these expectations not always be met?
Expectation.Answer: Researchers might expect palynological analysis to provide clear insights into the paleoenvironmental conditions, such as vegetation changes and aridification processes. However, these expectations may not always be met due to factors like insufficient fossil preservation, limited sample size, or complex depositional environments that obscure clear signals in the pollen record.

Expectation.Question: Why might researchers expect the evolution of aridification in central Asia to be difficult to determine, and what factors could contribute to these challenges?
Expectation.Answer: Researchers might expect difficulty in determining the evolution of aridification in central Asia due to the chaotic stratigraphic age constraints in the region. Additional factors contributing to these challenges include the complex interplay of tectonic activity, global cooling, and regional geographical influences such as the rain shadow effect of surrounding mountain ranges.

Judgmental.Question: How would you evaluate the effectiveness of using palynological analysis to date geological formations in regions with ambiguous stratigraphic frameworks?
Judgmental.Answer: Palynological analysis is considered a good proxy for reconstructing paleoenvironmental conditions and determining the relative stratigraphic age, especially in regions where other dating methods like radiometric isotopes or paleomagnetism may not be applicable. However, the effectiveness can vary based on the availability and preservation of palynomorphs, the comprehensiveness of reference collections, and the clarity of stratigraphic boundaries in the field.

Assertion.Question: I'm not sure how palynological analysis can be effectively used to determine the relative stratigraphic age of formations in complex geological regions.
Assertion.Answer: Palynological analysis is a useful proxy to determine the relative stratigraphic age, especially in regions where other dating methods such as radiometric isotopes, palaeomagnetism, and mammalian stratigraphy may not be applicable or effective. By analyzing pollen and spore assemblages, researchers can make inferences about the age and environmental conditions during the deposition of the sedimentary formations.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand why there are challenges in establishing a clear stratigraphic dating framework in the West Kunlun region.
Assertion.Answer: The challenges in establishing a stratigraphic dating framework in the West Kunlun region are primarily due to ambiguous stratigraphic age constraints. This ambiguity hampers the understanding of both tectonic and environmental evolution, as well as the precise timing of aridification in the Asian interior.

Assertion.Question: I can't figure out how modern top-soil pollen samples contribute to the reconstruction of past environments.
Assertion.Answer: Modern top-soil pollen samples are collected to provide a baseline for comparison with fossil pollen samples. By comparing these with the ancient pollen assemblages, researchers can infer changes in vegetation and climate over time, thereby helping to reconstruct past environments.

Request/Directive.Question: Please describe the challenges faced in establishing a stratigraphic dating framework in regions with ambiguous geological records.
Request/Directive.Answer: The main challenge in establishing a stratigraphic dating framework in regions with ambiguous geological records is the chaotic stratigraphic age constraints that hinder understanding of both tectonic and environmental evolution. This ambiguity has led to difficulties in determining the timing of aridification processes in the Asian interior, particularly in the West Kunlun region, due to inconsistent age reporting of formations like the Xialafudie Formation. Reliance on palynomorphs for relative stratigraphic dating and the limited application of other dating methods add to these challenges.
